proofOfAuthenticity.title: Proof of Authenticity

confidenceIndex.title: Confidence Index
confidenceIndex.subtitle: Our system monitors data for anomalies using statistical and density-based detection techniques. Any outlier data is flagged so the consumer contract can determine how to handle it.

externalAuditors.title: External Auditors

page.title: A new standard for on-chain data

verifiedPartnerships.title: Verified partnerships
verifiedPartnerships.description: Commercial relationships with trusted data providers through licensing agreements with research institutes, government agencies, specialized data companies.

cryptographicSecurity.title: Cryptographic security
cryptographicSecurity.description: Each provider receives a unique cryptographic key registered on-chain, acting as a tamper-proof signature for all submitted data.

onChainValidation.title: On-Chain validation
onChainValidation.description: Each data point is signed with a unique cryptographic key. After that, Fact Finance verifies authenticity before publishing it on-chain.

automation.title: Automation
automation.description: Allows protocols to automate responses based on data classification.

precision.title: Precision
precision.description: Uses statistical analysis and LOF for accurate anomaly detection.

riskManagement.title: Risk management

scalability.title: Scalability

consensusChecks.title: Consensus checks

reserves.title: Fact Finance - Transparency and Trust for the Web3 Ecosystem

hero.title: Proof of Reserves for
hero.subtitle: We connect offchain collateral and track onchain token supply, bringing both into a dynamic dashboard that enables transparency and trust for tokenized assets.

directConnection.title: Direct connection to off-chain reserves
directConnection.description: We connect to custodians, banks, or financial systems via secure APIs or validated files to extract real-world collateral data.

liveTracking.title: Live tracking of token issuance
liveTracking.description: We monitor the smart contract of the token to track the circulating supply and match it against the verified reserve data.

oracles.title: Oracles that publish data onchain
oracles.description: Using three oracle models (Push, Pull, Signature), we publish reserve data to smart contracts — with triggers like heartbeat or deviation.

dashboard.title: Real-time dashboard for transparency
dashboard.description: Our public dashboards display balances, update history, token supply, and onchain contract links — enabling full visibility and trust.

faq.heading: Everything you need to know about

whatIsPor.question: What is Proof of Reserves (PoR)?
whatIsPor.answer: Proof of Reserves is a method to publicly demonstrate that tokenized assets are backed by real-world collateral. Fact Finance automates this process by connecting to custodians and publishing verified reserve data onchain.

updateFrequency.question: How often is the reserve data updated?
updateFrequency.answer: Updates follow two rules: a heartbeat frequency (e.g., every 10 minutes) that ensures regular updates, and a deviation threshold that triggers a new update only when the reserve balance changes beyond a defined percentage (e.g., ±2%).

collateralizationStatus.question: What does the collateralization status mean?
collateralizationStatus.answer: If the status is over-collateralized, it means the verified reserves exceed the circulating token supply — indicating a safety buffer and room for new issuance. If it's under-collateralized, it means the reserves are not sufficient to fully back the issued tokens — signaling a potential risk and the need for corrective action.

tokenTracking.question: How does Fact Finance track token issuance?
tokenTracking.answer: We monitor the onchain token supply by tracking the smart contract of the token. This data is compared to the verified reserves to ensure ongoing collateral coverage, and the result is displayed in a public dashboard.

traditionalAudit.question: How is this different from a traditional audit?
traditionalAudit.answer: Fact Finance is not an audit firm and does not issue an opinion about the collateral. Instead, we provide a real-time transparency layer by connecting directly to custodians and publishing verified reserve data onchain.

cta.subtitle: Discover how Fact Finance can bring more transparency, security and credibility to your tokenized assets.

whatIsOracle.title: What is an oracle?
whatIsOracle.content: An oracle bridges real-world data to the blockchain, enabling smart contracts to execute based on real-world events.

whyTokenizedAssets.title: Why do tokenized assets need oracles?
whyTokenizedAssets.content: Oracles provide the real-world data that tokenized assets need to function accurately, such as property valuations for Real Estate tokens or interest rates and inflation for private credit tokens. Without oracles, tokenized assets cannot reflect real-time changes or off-chain events.

whatDataTypes.title: What types of data Fact Finance can provide?
whatDataTypes.content: We can provide various types of data, including market prices, economic indices, proof of reserves, square meter price for Real Estate, weather updates, and more, depending on the use case. Contact us if your project needs any other specific data.

dataSource.title: Where does Fact Finance source its data?
dataSource.content: Our data feeds come directly from official sources, such as central banks, research institutes and financial institutions.

integration.title: How do I integrate Fact Finance's APIs into my project?
integration.content: Our documentation provides step-by-step guides, API references, and examples for integration with EVM-based blockchains and Solana.

capitalMarkets.title: Capital markets
capitalMarkets.description: Access official economic indices from authorized sources
capitalMarkets.sectionTitle: Reshaping capital markets in Latin America
capitalMarkets.intro1: Tokenized capital markets are reshaping the financial landscape, especially in regions like Latin America, where high interest rates and inflation have historically shaped economic behavior. As investors seek to protect real returns, tokenization is emerging as a powerful tool to modernize financial systems.
capitalMarkets.intro2: Brazil is at the forefront of adopting blockchain for financial instruments. With the Central Bank developing its own DLT infrastructure and regulators collaborating with market players, tokenization has moved beyond theory to become a reality. This shift brings faster settlements, lower costs, and increased efficiency, all while keeping traditional market standards.
capitalMarkets.intro3: The rise of tokenization platforms signals a new era of financial innovation in Brazil. These companies are working closely with regulators to integrate smart contract programmability into the needs of the traditional financial system. The goal is to create the tokenized economy that maintains regulatory compliance while unlocking new efficiencies.
capitalMarkets.factFinanceRole: Fact Finance role connecting official data and tokenized assets
capitalMarkets.role1: In Brazil, approximately 45% of public debt is tied to the Selic (Interest rate), and another 30% to inflation-adjusted bonds. These indexed instruments dominate over 75% of the country's bond market. Beyond public debt, private long-term contracts, such as residential leases, also rely on inflation indexing, with the General Market Price Index (IGP-M) being a staple for rent price adjustments.
capitalMarkets.role2: Just like the traditional economy, the tokenized economy also needs to rely on accurate and verified economic data. Fact Finance provides seamless, secure on-chain access to economic indices, such as CDI (interest rate) and IGP-M (inflation), directly from official sources. Our oracle infrastructure acts as a data hub, integrating this information into tokenized assets like public bonds, private credit, and long-term contracts.
capitalMarkets.role3: By bridging real-world economic data with asset tokenization, Fact Finance enables tokenized assets to receive real-time price updates based on official data.

cdi.title: CDI
cdi.subtitle: (Interbank Deposit Certificate)
cdi.description: Daily or monthly on-chain updates of Brazil's key interest rate, enabling tokenized assets to reflect accurate returns tied to interest rate.

ipca.title: IPCA
ipca.subtitle: (Broad Consumer Price Index)
ipca.description: Official inflation data directly on-chain, ensuring tokenized contracts, such as bonds and leases, adjust automatically to preserve real value.

igpm.title: IGP-M
igpm.subtitle: (General Market Price Index)
igpm.description: Inflation-linked updates for sectors like Real estate, enabling accurate rent adjustments and reliable pricing for tokenized assets.

realEstate.title: Real Estate
realEstate.description: Square meter price and proof of reserve for properties
realEstate.sectionTitle: Unlocking value by reducing information asymmetry
realEstate.intro1: The tokenization of Real Estate offers the advantages of fractional ownership and the potential for increased liquidity, making these high-value assets more accessible to a broader range of investors within a tradable and programmable infrastructure. However, significant information asymmetries between the token and the off-chain asset it represents still limit its full potential. To unlock greater utility and liquidity, tokenized Real Estate assets must be enriched with verified, up-to-date data that provides a real-time connection to the underlying property.
realEstate.intro2: Tokenized properties offer greater accessibility, but blockchain technology lacks intrinsic connections to off-chain data. This creates a gap: while tokens can represent ownership, they do not inherently reflect the current market conditions of the real-world asset they are tied to. Fact Finance bridges this gap by serving as the data layer between tokenized assets and proprietary data sources. For example, a Real Estate company tokenizing a property needs the token to reflect more than just ownership, it must also carry the information of the market value for that asset, transforming the token into a true digital twin.

proofOfReserve.title: Proof of Reserve
proofOfReserve.description: To confirm that the token corresponds to a specific property, Fact Finance can provide on-chain information, such as: Address and geolocation, Legal status (Due Diligence), Property type (residential or commercial), year of construction.

squareMeterPrice.title: Square Meter Price
squareMeterPrice.description: To reflect property appreciation or depreciation, tokens require up-to-date regional price per square meter data. Fact Finance integrates directly with licensed data institutions to provide precise market pricing, enabling an up-to-date valuation of the property to be calculated.

economicIndices.title: Economic indices
economicIndices.description: Real estate contracts often require inflation adjustments. In Brazil, 90% of rental contracts are tied to the inflation index IGP-M. Fact Finance connects directly to this official data source, ensuring seamless inflation updates.

realEstate.reliableConnection: Here's how Fact Finance ensures a reliable connection:
realEstate.conclusion: With Fact Finance's integration, tokenized Real Estate moves beyond static representation to become a dynamic financial asset. Tokens can now serve as collateral for loans or be used in DeFi applications, unlocking greater utility and liquidity for both issuers and investors.

commodities.title: Commodities
commodities.description: Qualitative data and monitoring for commodities
commodities.intro1: Latin America's economies heavily rely on the commodities sector, driving global markets for agricultural goods, minerals, and energy. Despite its significance, this sector faces challenges such as operational inefficiencies, high transaction costs, and limited access to financing, particularly for smaller producers.
commodities.intro2: Tokenization provides a powerful solution by digitizing physical commodities, making them tradable and usable as collateral for financing. This unlocks liquidity for producers while enabling them to retain ownership of their assets.
commodities.riskReduction: Reducing risk with verified data for commodity tokenization
commodities.risk1: In lending markets, managing risk exposure is critical for both lenders and borrowers. Collateralized assets must be as transparent as possible to reduce perceived risk. In agriculture, for example, variables such as region, weather, grain type, and other qualitative factors significantly impact the associated risk score. Addressing these information asymmetries is key to unlocking tokenization's potential to expand financing to small producers.
commodities.risk2: Fact Finance bridges this gap by connecting tokenized assets, such as grains or livestock, to trusted data sources directly associated with the underlying commodities. This includes:

marketPrices.title: Market prices
marketPrices.description: Real-time pricing pulled directly from trusted exchanges like the CME (Chicago Mercantile Exchange).

qualitativeData.title: Qualitative data
qualitativeData.description: Information from farmers' ERP systems, such as productivity history, crop type, and operational timelines.

environmentalData.title: Environmental data
environmentalData.description: Weather conditions and climate forecasts that influence yield quality and asset value.

logisticsData.title: Logistics data
logisticsData.description: Key information such as proximity to ports or transportation hubs, affecting delivery efficiency and costs.

commodities.event1: By enriching tokens with real-time data, oracles can track off-chain events that directly affect the value or utility of tokenized assets. For example, an insurance smart contract for agricultural assets can use weather oracles to monitor events such as droughts or floods, automatically triggering payouts when predefined thresholds are met. Similarly, Fact Finance's oracles can flag significant changes, such as adverse weather conditions, that may require lenders to reassess loan terms.
commodities.event2: With this data integration, collateralized tokens become dynamic financial instruments rather than static representations, reducing risk and increasing transparency. This enables lending protocols to offer higher Loan-to-Value (LTV) ratios, giving producers greater access to financing without sacrificing control over their assets.

company.description1: Fact Finance was created to provide essential data infrastructure for the tokenized economy. We bridge tokenization platforms with official and licensed data sources, ensuring secure and compliant access to information. Our goal is to accelerate blockchain adoption by seamlessly connecting decentralized systems to the off-chain world.
company.description2: As tokenization evolves and the demand for standardized, reliable data grows, Fact Finance is committed to being the go-to data hub. We empower the industry with streamlined access to accurate and trustworthy information, unlocking the full potential of real-world asset tokenization

footnotes.heartbeat: The heartbeat is a timing rule that ensures updates happen at regular intervals. For example, with a 1-hour heartbeat, the system will attempt an update at least every 1 hour, even without major changes. This prevents data staleness and detects delays or outages quickly.
footnotes.deviation: The deviation threshold defines how much the reserve balance must change before a new onchain update is triggered. For instance, with a 5% threshold, the system only publishes a new value if the balance moves by 5% or more since the last update. This avoids unnecessary updates due to minor fluctuations.
footnotes.tokensSupply: Tokens Supply is the total amount of tokens currently in circulation, issued by the tokenization platform. Each unit should be backed by a verified reserve, ensuring a transparent 1:1 or over-collateralized ratio.
footnotes.collateralReserves: Collateral reserves are real-world assets, such as cash or public securities, held to back issued tokens. Fact Finance verifies their existence and value through direct connections with the custodian.
footnotes.collateralization: Over or under collateralization refers to the difference between the verified reserves and the circulating token supply. A positive gap indicates excess collateral (a safety buffer), while a negative gap signals insufficient reserves and potential undercollateralization risk.
